response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use the following code to iterate through a 2D map:
```css
Map<String, Map<String, String>> centralMap = new HashMap<>();
Map<String, String> nestedMap = new HashMap<>();

// Add some entries to the centralMap
centralMap.put("key1", nestedMap);
centralMap.put("key2", nestedMap);

// Define the iterator method
private Iterator<Map.Entry<String, Map<String, String>>> iterator() {
    return new Iterator<Map.Entry<String, Map<String, String>>>() {
        private Map.Entry<String, Map<String, String>> currentEntry = null;

        {
            currentEntry = centralMap.entrySet().iterator();
        }

        @Override
        public boolean hasNext() {
            return currentEntry != null;
        }

        @Override
        public Map.Entry<String, Map<String, String>> next() {
            if (!hasNext()) {
                throw new NoSuchElementException();
            }

            Map.Entry<String, Map<String, String>> entry = currentEntry.next();
            currentEntry = entry.getValue().entrySet().iterator();
            return entry;
        }

        @Override
        public void remove() {
            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
        }
    };
}
```
This iterator will return the entries in the centralMap in the order they were added. To remove an element through the iterator, you can throw an UnsupportedOperationException as shown in the code above.

Explanation: The iterator method uses a while loop to iterate through the entry set of the centralMap and return the entries in the order they were added. The hasNext() method returns true as long as there is at least one entry left in the centralMap. The next() method returns the current entry and then sets the currentEntry to the next entry in the nested map. If there are no more entries left, it throws a NoSuchElementException. The remove() method is not supported and throws an UnsupportedOperationException.
